ranked_diseases.explanation: Hyperuricemia is a hallmark feature of Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome, which is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT).

ranked_diseases.disease_name: Glycogen Storage Disease Type Ia (von Gierke Disease)
ranked_diseases.explanation: Hyperuricemia can occur in Glycogen Storage Disease Type Ia due to increased production and decreased excretion of uric acid.
This condition is characterized by hyperuricemia and progressive renal failure, often presenting in adolescence.
PRPS1 superactivity leads to overproduction of uric acid, resulting in hyperuricemia and associated symptoms.
Partial deficiency of HPRT can cause hyperuricemia without the full spectrum of Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome.
